Cats do roar, I geuss you've never seen a real angry cat. It is higher pitched depending on how small the animal is because of simple physics. Smaller shorter vocal cords naturally vibrate at higher frequencies... like the shorter strings on a piano. They can actually growl low like a dog too if they're angry, but it's harder for them to do, so it's not as loud as a dog's growl.

I disagree on the smell thing, as I have tracked people, and a whole bunch of other things, it is just a bit undignified, as the nose needs to be close to ground for best results, but absolutely doable, and you become better at it with time if you practice. As a result I tend to know who is around me without seeing them, just based on the smell that emanates from them. So I am quite certain I would be capable of their abilities, and maybe even surpass it due to the ridiculous amount of neurons dedicated to this sense. Interestingly humans have better equipment then even dogs to decode the inputs form olfactories, so we might have less olfactories, but they are significantly more effective due to the underlying support from more neurons actually processing the info. The idea that humans have poor smell is a myth created to explain freewill, story goes in comparison to brain size, less of our brain size is dedicated to the olfactory bulb, which in and off it self is correct, however this was assumed that the frontal lobe has taken the place of the olfactory bulb, and thus at the expense of smell we have become more self aware, however the key thing here is the human brain is massive in comparison to cats and dogs, giving us a distinct advantage over processing the information because physically in real terms the olfactory bulb is bigger then cats and dogs, because our brains are so much bigger then theirs, and thus even though a smaller percentage of the brain is focused on smell, the size of the brain far outweighs other smaller animals, and is so doing not only makes up for it, but exceeds that of other smaller animals.

Cats have the ultimate life, we're their slave robots who open doors and can openers for us except we're often very poorly trainable with minds of our own even though the cat's communication is so clear.

But on a serious note: I'm always surprised by people who get scratched by cats, they send a million warning signals (swatting, growling, warning nips and light scratches and before that MANY body language signs) before the claws actually come out and even then they seldom actually use full force. My favourite game is to get kittehs ready to play, get my hand completely trapped in the cat trap of jaws and teeth and then keep completely still. Without fail when I stop struggling they all lose interest in following through and they either loosen their grip so I can escape, or push or kick my hand away at this surrender/playing dead so I only get the lightest of scratches. If I HAD managed to get scratched by that time I certainly wouldn't blame the cat.

Respect cats' boundaries and they'll respect you. If they're growling or sending warning signals or playful signals they tend to be extremely obvious. I never understand how people get scratches on their face - what's your face doing so close to a creature that barely comes up to your knee? Generally that's YOUR fault, don't go doing inhumane things like declawing a cat simply for having boundaries, if you don't want to get scratched respect the cat's boundaries, don't play if you don't know how to read when the cat wants to be left alone. They send the most obvious body language signals of any creature I've ever met, way more obvious and consistent than humans in the warnings they give. Plus a lot of their responses they can't really help if they get overstimulated so don't blame them if you get scratched, learn from Jackson Galaxy how to calm them down.

The only time I've had deep scratches were one time I volunteered my arm to be a springboard for a cat leaping from a tree (clearly accidental from the cat and I should've just gotten out of the way but I was a kinda dumb teen), and when my sister's dog pawed my calf in a painful friendly manner with his nails which were exceptionally long and needed a trim. I've had cats my entire life and every time I went to visit someone they'd always warn me that their cat was scratchy and vicious and that was never the case. I'm in my 30s now and always gravitated towards cats at people's houses (no, I didn't pet strays because I still want to be smart and safe - was warned about diseases and never assumed they were tame or wanted to be petted and didn't want to encourage them to trust strange humans who might be bad people so I'm not advocating people should take silly risks or be as playful with housecats as I am either, just that people should read cats' body language and treat them and their boundaries with respect rather than imposing your will on the cat and then getting angry it didn't want to play. In my experience, besides being playful, house cats respect people who respect them, and chasing your feet or swiping playfully as you go past is a far cry from the type of deep scratches that would only come from a serious fight with a cat. A

lso, all that aside, there is no excuse for declawing or any other type of animal abuse. Just don't have an animal or a kid if you're not willing to learn the proper way to take care of them - you choose to have them in order to serve and love them unconditionally, they're not there to fulfil or complete you, fulfil your insecurities and they don't owe you anything. If you didn't get a choice to have them don't take it out on them, they certainly didn't choose this life.

Domestic cats have a higher degree of neoteny.  I foster feral kittens, and I can tell you that even as bottle raised babies to full grown adults, their personalities are very different.  Generations of breeding that only favors the best hunters and most clever survivors leads to behaviors that are much closer to their ancestors.  My theory is that cats are always 2 generations away from reverting to wild animals.

FYI, there was no "Palestine" in the Fertile Crescent.  If you want to talk about pre--Abrahmic land that is now called Israel/Palestine, use the word Canaanite.  Palestine was the name that the Roman conquerors gave to the land of Israel.  The land was for many years part of the Ottoman Empire, and when the British Mandate took over they used the name Palestine.  There isn't even a letter P in the Arabic alphabet, so how could it be called that?

We now know that cats are attracted to catnip because it acts as an insect repellent. It doesn't mimic pheromones. If that were the case, they would exhibit a flehmen response in the presence of catnip, which they don't. They actually have a response in their opioid receptors in response to the smell of catnip, which provides a brief feeling of euphoria that makes them want to roll around in it. And that protects them from insect bites.

3:40 there is a legend of an extinct Chinese cat called the Chinese Lop-Eared Cat, that used to be a pet hunting cat in ancient China. There are records of this cat, and paintings too, but most were made by foreigners who did not speak fluent Chinese; which perhaps makes their stories less believable. If this cat did exist, or something similar to this cat did exist, there is a chance that it was domesticated separately from other cats as they were often described as being larger, with big floppy ears; an animal that closely resembled cats, but not exactly. There are also records of pure white, blue eyed cats that were lapcats of rich ladies, most likely because they were either deaf or blind as most white and blue eyed cats are. Thus they were unable to hunt, but were still used as house pets.

"while you might enjoy your home at 24°C..."

Whoa, ease up there!

I'd heard personal preference for room temperature generally ranges from about 18°C - 22°C (~64.5°F - 71.5°F) depending on the person and situation.

Personally I'm on the lower end of that range, preferring 18 when I'm in bed (with a thin blanket), and 20 or 21 if I'm sitting totally still and relaxing for a long time (like watching TV on the sofa)

I find 24°C (~75°F) is barely comfortable; only if I'm extremely sedentary and relaxed for an extended period. If I'm active at all (even just cognitively) I find it oppressively stuffy. I'll be very surprised if 24 is commonly considered comfortable by many people!

I’m surprised there was no mention of cats’ Jacobson’s organ (the same mechanism snakes smell with.) When cats rub on you then lick that spot, they aren’t trying to wash off your scent, they’re picking it up with their tongue and depositing in in that organ on the roof of their mouth to get a better sense of you. It’s not as refined or sensitive as a snake’s but it another piece of the amazing sensory world-building toolkit cats possess. It’s also comforting to know your cat isn’t trying to wash you off, but rather getting to know you better.

I used to have a cat. She hated everyone but me. We never verbally communicated, but after 10 years of being best friends we'd figured out exactly what the other wanted with just body language. I knew when she wanted food, water, attention, outside, to be warmer (she had arthritis) etc. She knew when I was upset, sore, happy, or lonely. She'd come and cuddle up to me when I was upset. She wouldn't even leave me to use the bathroom. She would come in every few minutes to make sure I was okay. Because of my autism, I'm funny about any kind of physical contact, but I never pushed her away. Then when I moved out of home, I left her with my parents. She was getting older,  and I didnt want to move her around because I was scared she would die if I did. My parents told me she waited by the door for months, waiting for me to come home. After about 6 months of this, she died. I remember getting a call from my parents telling me she was on her way out. When I got there her organs were already shutting down. I had to bury her on my own. Even two and a half years later I still break down when I think about her. She was closer to me than any person in my life, even my family. I feel like it's my fault she died when she did. Like if I had have stayed there she'd still be around. She was only 10 when she died, and cats live for up to 20 years on average..... I feel so guilty

My family had a cat, Patsy, A small tuxedo male that was neutered late. He had a huge ego and was a truly great spirit. Though small he ruled the house. He was horribly injured and almost died defending another housecat from a marauding stray German Shepard that escaped a neighborhood house. While both my beloved Fido, a very delicate and feminine Persian, and the attacking dog (blinded by Patsy in the attack) died because of their injuries, Patsy lived on to beyond 20 years of age. He was the toughest, most masculine and self confident creature I have had the privileged of knowing. I said "great spirit" and i meant it.


That cat was unflappable. Neighbors were adopted after they moved in by a giant rough Tom they named Beast. Beast was truly an "outside cat" but showed up when he needed a meal. In exchange he brought my neighbors presents, usually opossums the size of Patsy or larger. His torn ears and many scars were evidence of a life lived on the road, finding comfort where he pleased and bringing death to many a creature. Beast was the biggest "domesticated" cat I have ever seen. If Patsy heard the rattle of kibble into a dish next door he would run over and shoulder Beast out of the way until his belly was full. Beast never complained, just watching quizzically.


I say all this, and there is much more I could say, to set the stage, to give you an glimpse of understanding into patsy's weakness. While Patsy enjoyed marijuana, he would come and ask for the smoke to be blown into his face (hey, it was the '70s), he had no weakness to catnip. Cantaloupes, however, were quire another matter. He LOVED cantaloupes, not the flesh, just the skin. he would chew it, gnaw it, wallow in it, and become hopelessly intoxicated.


This wasn't a casual attraction. I have had the misfortune of knowing a couple junkies. Their craving for heroine and the crimes they would commit to obtain it did not match Patsy's drive. put one in the fridge and he would open the fridge, leave it open, and wallow in the smashed fruit on the floor as the milk spoiled. Hide a cantaloupe in the top kitchen cupboard and he will roll it out to smash on the floor and lie in it drunken and disabled with a dislocated hip, but not a care in the world. He would lie there, broken and disheveled, staring back up at me with this stupid grin as if to say "Isn't this great!"


Almost 40 years later I still miss that cat, and i'm not a 'cat person.' He still visits me in my dreams. When we have cantaloupe I always leave some skins out where he can find it.

Domesticated cats also seem to be the most social of cats other than lions. If left on their own to become feral, they often form social colonies. So they tend to hang out in groups that they only leave to hunt. Now the question was whether this tendency was there before being domesticated, but if it was, the social trait may have made domestication easier.

Also some cats seem to like the cold. Probably has to do with the type of fur and individual differences in metabolism and size. So the warm thing in regards to the boxes (near the end of the video) isn't always the case. I've got a cat that seeks out cool rather than warmer spaces, but he's got a bit of thicker fur and perhaps more body fat than the others too.

Regarding the effectiveness of catnip on cats: In some regions of the world where cats were introduced later, "founder effects" can have a lot to do with it. For example, something like 9 in 10 cats in New Zealand simply aren't interested it, and consequently you basically can't find any products with catnip in them there.

. Don't declaw your cats, it's cutting off the last digit of their fingers, it's life long difficulty walking and earlier arthritis, they simply can't move as well since they are walking with significant ends of their feet taken off, and a toes of a cat are more important than toes of a human.

Instead trim the nails ever so often when they get too sharp with a regular human fingernail clipper, turn it perpendicular to the claw, sideways, as the nails are very flat and thin. Be mindful not to trim claws too far in, there is a fluid in the nail called a quick that you can cut into, I don't remember what it does but it's important to not cut into it, it causes problems. You can see this fluid if the nail is not too discolored, especially in younger cats. And once you have an idea where it is you can get a idea about avoiding it. But generally speaking as long as you don't cut the claw past the point where it starts getting thicker, you'll be alright. Just trim off those sharp ends for less pain and destruction.

I am a big fan of education when it comes to cohabitation with other animals, humans included. I would like to see a video on best practices when it comes to hygiene related to domestication and cohabitation, remind people the need of sanitation and cleanliness of cat areas to reduce bacterial, fungal and viral build up that may cause recurring exposures and long term illnesses in cats and humans alike. This goes both ways, animals will be affected by us in this manner also so reducing contact with animals and maintaining appropriate contact is best... this mean not letting your cat lick your face or body, maintain space because infection is bi directional, washing your hands before and after touching the animal... this is not easy. At a minimum wash before consuming food or drink or touching anything food related, wash all surfaces before touching food because cats like counters. Litter boxes need daily or more maintenance and routine replacement of media and disinfection of the area and boxes. Do not use your cats as mousers or expect them to do all the dirty work pest wise, keep traps for mice and rats and remove the body immediately, if your cat does catch something do not let it eat it, dispose of and clean up. A show simply on parasites would be good to show people the dangers and methods of contact. I could chat on the subject for days. I dont and wont have a cat but I do love them and hope people choose to have a cat wisely and invest the time... training is another show and being trained.

I’m surprised there was no mention of cats’ Jacobson’s organ (the same mechanism snakes smell with.) When cats rub on you then lick that spot, they aren’t trying to wash off your scent, they’re picking it up with their tongue and depositing in in that organ on the roof of their mouth to get a better sense of you. It’s not as refined or sensitive as a snake’s but it another piece of the amazing sensory world-building toolkit cats possess. It’s also comforting to know your cat isn’t trying to wash you off, but rather getting to know you better.
